utterances: Haddad also spoke about Iran, flatly denying reports alleging that Morsi had told an Iranian news outlet that he wanted closer ties with Tehran.
This was an entire hearsay story.
It was made up by one of the Egyptian newswires, unfortunately.
Since the second round of elections, Dr. Morsi, President Morsi has not made a single interview with any press agency.
Publisher and analyst Hisham Kassem told Al Jazeera's English-language channel that fears that Egypt might suddenly embrace Tehran are overblown for two reasons.
First, the Egyptian military retains power over major foreign policy moves.
And second, the Muslim Brotherhood doesn't support Tehran's regional ambitions any more than the military does.
If we start getting too close to Iran, we're going to antagonize the Gulf and the Trans-Atlantic at once.
And again, it's not in our best interest that Iran acquires a nuclear weapon at any cost.
Persian Gulf analyst Mustafa al-Ani, at the Geneva-based Gulf Research Center, says if Egypt wants to normalize diplomatic ties with Iran that's one thing.
But any move to ally itself with Tehran will cost Egypt something it can't afford to lose - the financial backing of wealthy Gulf states, led by Saudi Arabia.
Another source of anxiety surrounding Egypt's new president is the rising profile of the Muslim Brotherhood around the region.
The Brotherhood-influenced Hamas runs the Gaza Strip, and the Syrian Muslim Brothers are a powerful component of the rebellion against the regime in Damascus.
The Brothers are a noticeable presence in Kuwait, and are causing serious concern among the rulers of Jordan, the other Arab state to have a peace treaty with Israel.

Veteran Egyptian analyst Abdel Monem Saeed says it's ironic that Jordan's King Abdullah, who a decade ago warned of an Iranian-led Shiite crescent of power forming in the Middle East, is now worried about the Sunni Muslim Brotherhood.
Saeed believes what Jordan is really concerned about is an Arab Spring uprising against a monarchy that refuses to enact political reforms.
DR.
ABDEL MONEM SAEED: That did not happen in Jordan.
And King Abdullah, he has an anxiety about the Muslim Brothers in cooperation.
Because the model we got is actually revolutions are made by youth, by discontent, and then the Muslim Brothers come with their organizational, financial abilities to the fore.
But Saeed and other analysts agree that if there is to be a rise of the Brothers, Egypt won't have much of a role in it anytime soon.
Mohammed Morsi will be far too busy struggling to cope with a deeply entrenched military and a devastated economy.
Peter Kenyon, NPR News, Cairo.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
Judgment Day is May 21st.
That is, if you trust the many billboards popping up across the country.
One group of Christians predicts catastrophe will strike that day, taking the true believers to heaven and leaving the rest to a terrible fate.
NPR's Barbara Bradley Hagerty reports that few people genuinely believe the end of days is upon us, but prophesies of the Apocalypse are definitely on the rise.
Judgment Day, folks, May the 21st, 2011.

Well, one sticking point we haven't been hearing about for a while but certainly has been an issue for Iraqis both on the street and in the government, is the issue of immunity for troops and perhaps more importantly for contractors.

I mean as I'm sure people know there have been a lot of civilian killings by contractors and by troops over the years and a lot of Iraqis feel that our troops and our contractors should not be immuned from that.
But our negotiators do not feel that troops - I mean they're very firm on the point that troops must have immunity.
They seem to be a little more willing to talk about the contractors issue saying that they did not start - that they understand that this is a point that they need to have more discussions on.
But we have not heard about any agreement on that point yet.
NPR's Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson in Baghdad on the important negotiations that were supposed to conclude this week in Baghdad.
Soraya thank you.
You're welcome.
This is NEWS AND NOTES.
I'm Farai Chideya.
On today's Roundtable, President Bush's poll numbers are up and Democrats aren't happy; and the AFL-CIO invest $1 billion in New Orleans developments.
Joining us today from our headquarters in Washington, D.C., economist and author, Julianne Malveaux, President and CEO of the Last Word Production.
In our New York bureau, we have Michael Meyers.
Actually, I'm sorry.
He's joining us by phone.
And also Walter Fields, CEO and publisher of the NorthStarNetwork.com is at KISS FM in New York.
Thank you all for joining us.
Good to be here, Farai.
Thank you.
So let's start out with this Gallup Poll that has Democrats worried.
Apparently now that Abu Musab al-Zarqawi has been terminated, more Americans are feeling confident about the war in Iraq; forty-eight percent believe the U.S.
probably or definitely will win the war.
That's up from 39 percent in April.
Does the president have momentum here?
Osama bin Laden's still AWOL.
Is this the beginning of a resurgence, Julianne, for the Bush administration?
Oh, not at all.
Certainly, the administration has every right to revel in two victories.
One the - as you put it, termination - I like that - of al-Zarqawi, but also Mr. Bush's surprise visit to Baghdad.
I mean, those are two things that have boosted momentum, have probably boosted the morale of our troops, and have made the county feel as if we're in control of this thing.
But, as was reported just a few minutes ago, Farai, our casualties have exceeded 2,500 now, and you can never count on the environment in Iraq.
Good today, bad tomorrow, you still have people - as Ed's interview just showed -who are very, very adamant about, you know, the whole situation in the Middle East.
There are people who are not backing down.
Getting al-Zarqawi was just one thing, and it's like there's someone else who's coming to replace him.
This is, however, a good time for Republicans because, as you say, Democrats are in disarray.
The Campaign for America's Future Conference, Take Back the Future, that met here in Washington earlier this week, Hillary was booed because she does not support a time certain to move the troops.
And it just goes to show - she's supposedly the frontrunner.
Much of her speech was very wildly applauded, but then she was booed.
It just goes to show the schizophrenia in the Democratic Party, and until those folks can get some therapy, the Republicans basically rise to the top.
Well, Julianne, let me ask you.
Who are those folks?
Those folks the Democratic identified voters?
Those folks, the Democrats who are in office?
Tell me more about what you mean.
Well, I think it's the Democratic leadership.
I think that the people have been consistent with concerns about the economy and things like tax cuts.
The people are concerned about things like employment.
The people, by and large, even with this approval rating - 48 percent is not a great number.
The people do not like this war, but you have Democrats talking out of four sides of their mouth.
You know, it's the Rodney King thing: can we all get along?
Especially when you look at, you know, someone like Hillary who is so wildly popular, but still tries to cleave to the center.
The party, literally, in my opinion, is in disarray.
There have been more than enough opportunities in the past six months, as the Republicans have floundered on all kinds of things, for the Democrats to step up and take leadership.
And they haven't done it.
But Hillary believes she's wildly popular because she's in the center.
Generally, I agree...
Like I said, therapy.
I agree with Julianne.
But, you know, this is what I regard as a knee-jerk bounce from America's second We Got Him.
We have to remember what Gore Vidal said in mocking the president, this is a wartime president, wartime president.
And people are knee-jerk with respect to the news.
If it's good, they feel better.
If it's bad, they feel awful.
But, you know, the body - they still don't see the body bags, and people are still dying.
This is a superficial, public relations gimmickry.
I mean, Julianne used the word surprise trip.
I use the word secret trip.
And the emphasis must be on secret, because Iraq is a very dangerous place.
It's dangerous for the president.
It's dangerous for the people who are living there.
It's dangerous for the people who are trying to govern the place.
And yes, Julianne is right again when she says the Republicans benefit from Democrats being deeply divided over Iraq and the disarray of the Democratic leadership between themselves.
I mean, Joe Lieberman could very well go down in Connecticut because of his (unintelligible).
All right.
Well, let me turn to Walter.
I'm going to make you role-play here for a second.

You're Hillary Clinton, and besides having to get pumps and a completely different wardrobe, how do you reach out to both Democrats who are centrists, Democrats who are far left, and at least a few Republicans?
You really can't.
You have to decide who you are.
And I think the Democrats major problem and why their prospects could dim in November is the fact that their politics is so poll-driven.
And I think what the country is looking for right now is real leadership.
Margaret Pease stands on a corner in downtown Pittsburgh, handing out doomsday pamphlets.
For the past seven months she's been crisscrossing the country in a caravan with eight others, warning anyone who will listen that God's wrath is near.
NOAR(ph) (Saudi Arabian Student): That's what I think.
Maybe because Muslims mostly are frustrated.
Everything is now against us, you know.
So maybe someday their voice will be louder because I also heard that the most religion increasing here in the United States is Islam.
Right, day by day it's increasing so--and you're the most powerful country in the world.
So then they might come--leaders from your country--and speak out the real Islam and how peaceful it is.
OK.
My name is Noar and I'm from Saudi Arabia.

Aha, this is called Apache, this is called F-16.
So it's really miserable.
It's really not good when a child knows the names of tools of destruction instead of names of toys and playing as a normal child.

I'd like to say that we are all--after all, we are all human beings, and people in our countries think the same way people here think.
You don't have to feel the superiority to others.
OK?

OK?

Our original book and our only book is holy Koran.

For example, our prophet say when there is a war you have to fight.
They stop at this point.
You have to fight.
Fight for who?
Fight where?
It doesn't matter.
You know, they talk the beginning of a sentence and they stop.
Continue for this saying.
You have to fight soldiers.
There is a war, there is a fight, fight the soldiers.
Never fight the people.
Unidentified Man #5: Also the extremists in any religion would interpret anything just to make an excuse for their extremists.
Unidentified Woman #4: In our church that people are extremists only in religion and politics, and they are the two--the only two problems in the world.
OK?
